bibl.title: Letter from Robert H. Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, August 31, 1950

div1.p: Robert Kean writes that his father, Jefferson Randolph Kean, is a patient at Walter Reed Hospital.

div1.head: Letter from Robert H. Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, August 31, 1950

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
August 31/50

div1.p:
This does not bring you
very good news from Georgetown, as
my father is far from well at Walter
Reed, but I know you woud not
want to be without word of it-

He went out there about
two weeks ago and during last week
it became evident that surgery
would be necessary - prostate.
Col Kimbrough planned a prostatectomy
but just prior to the operation, due to
AC
K
a rather sharp drop in blood pressure,
had recourse, under local anesthesia
to insertion of a tube through the abdominal
wall into the bladder, without removal
of the gland.

He came along fairly well until last
night when he had what appears to be
a slight stroke. This morning the
hospital reported that he could answer
questions but that there seemed to be
some paralysis of the left arm-
More recently they report him resting fairly
comfortably without much change-

I hope this unprofessional lay,
report is intelligible though I fear
it undoubtedly raises more questions
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
in your mind, than it answers - as such
reports are opt to do- I will try
to send you further reports from
time to time-

Mrs Kean asks me to add
her greetings & good wishes to my
own-
